title: Plan the deployment
content:
Your deployment plan varies depending on the product components ("capabilities") that you choose to deploy and the size of your environment. To create a deployment plan: 
  1. Choose a deployment option
  2. Choose a deployment size
  3. Calculate the hardware resource requirements
  • The sizing recommendations are the minimum dedicated resources required for running the suite (lab tests indicate the average CPU usage is 40 ~ 60%, and memory usage is 75 ~ 85%). The sizing recommendations below don't consider the following:
    • Any other applications that you may run in the environment, especially high resource-consuming software such as antivirus or mining software
    • The extra load as the volume of tickets in the system increases over time
  • For node high availability, better system performance, and stability in production, you can add one or two extra worker nodes. This is important especially if you have a different user load, business throughput, and data volume size or if you're uncertain about your business needs.
  • You must use external databases in a production environment. Using a physical database server for the suite can help you achieve optimal performance.
  • In a production environment, to avoid a single point of failure, use three control plane nodes to achieve high availability supported by the failover mechanism of the suite. The sizing information below has taken this recommendation into account. However, if you still want to deploy only one control plane node, use the same hardware configurations (worker nodes, database, and NFS storage) as described below, except that you use one control plane node instead of three. Meanwhile, you need to follow the backup procedures as described in the backup and restore section.

Choose a deployment option

Capability installation considerations

Different capabilities meet different business needs. During installation, you can select the capabilities according to your business needs. Apart from the basic "Service Management" capability that will install an agent interface, a Service Portal (self-service user interface), and a Suite Administration portal (suite administrator interface), you can optionally install the capabilities described in Install add-on capabilities (Helm). 

Some of the add-on capabilities require extra hardware resources. 

UCMDB installation considerations

The SAM and Native SACM solutions require (and share) an integration with UCMDB. For more information about Native SACM and SAM, see Enable SAM and Enable Native SACM. Decide on which of the following types of CMDB you want to use:

  • Classic UCMDB (traditional, non-containerized UCMDB)
  • Containerized UCMDB (installed through Helm as the next deployment on the same OMT cluster)

Typical deployment options

The following are typical deployment options based on capability combinations for different use cases:

  • Option 1: Service Management only
  • Option 2: Service Management + SAM + UCMDB
  • Option 3: Service Management +DND + OO Containerized + Cloud Cost Reporting

Each capability has its own deployment size definitions. Sizing recommendations are available for each option, based on an assumption that all capabilities of the option have the same deployment size (Small, Medium, or Large).  
If none of the deployment options meets your needs, you can calculate your hardware requirements by manually adding up all hardware resources required for your desired capabilities. 

Option 1. Install Service Management only

Use this option if you plan to install only the Service Management capability. The following diagram illustrates the architecture of this deployment option. 


 

Option 2. Install Service Management + SAM  + UCMDB

Use this option if you plan to install the Service Management and SAM capabilities (and optionally enable Native SACM). The following diagrams illustrate the architecture of this deployment option, using classic UCMDB or the standalone containerized UCMDB, respectively. 

To use the SAM and Native SACM solutions, you need an integration with UCMDB (UCMDB Server and UCMDB Gateway). 

Service Management + SAM + classic UCMDB
Service Management + SAM + Containerized UCMDB

Option 3. Install Service Management +DND + OO Containerized + Cloud Cost Reporting

Use this option if you plan to install the Service Management together with the DND and Cloud Cost Reporting capabilities (which the Cloud Management functionality requires). 

The installation of Operations Orchestration(OO) Containerized is mandatory for DND to work. After installing DND, install and enable OO Containerized. See Install OO on-premises and Enable OO Containerized.

Installing and enabling OO Containerized should be completed before enabling DND in the suite administration.

The following diagram illustrates the architecture of this deployment option. 

Note: Cloud Cost Reporting needs a Vertica database.

      Calculate the capability deployment sizes

      The following are size definitions for the Service Management, SAM, and DND capabilities, and sizing considerations for the Cloud Cost Reporting capability. 

      Service Management size definitions

      During the installation, you will need to select a deployment size: Small, Medium, or Large, so that the suite installer automatically scales the suite deployment according to the selected size. Use the following table to calculate your deployment size.  
       

      Deployment Size Small Medium Large Notes
      Maximum number of concurrent users (including both Service Portal users and IT agent users) 100 ~ 400 400 ~ 1000 1000 ~ 3000 Concurrent users are active users who have logged in to the system to perform operations and consume system resources. There are two types of concurrent users: service portal users and IT agent users. The workload for each type of users is as follows:
      • Service portal users: After logging in to the system, each portal user has a session duration of about 30 minutes on the system. They create 1 ~ 2 orders or requests.
      • IT agent users: IT agent users have a longer session duration, and each of them is active for about 1.5 hours after login and handles 4 ~ 6 tickets.

      Calculate the business operation throughput based on the workload assumption described earlier in this topic. For example, for 400 service portal users, the number of newly created orders or requests will be 800 ~ 1600 per hour, while for 400 IT agent users, the number of handled tickets will be 1000 ~ 1600 per hour. If you have a much larger business operation throughput than the numbers provided here, consider adding more worker nodes.

      User count conversion:
      The user count numbers assume that you will have only Service Management users. Conduct user count conversion if you plan to deploy both Service Management tenants and Service Manager tenants. 

      In general, 1 Service Manager user is equal to 0.7 Service Management users, because a Service Manager tenant consumes only Service Portal in the container.
      Example: If your deployment needs to support 400 Service Manager tenant concurrent users and 100 Service Management tenant concurrent users, the actual user count is: 400 X 0.7 + 100 = 380. So you need to select the Small size.
      Maximum number of records in Smart Analytics 1 Million 2 Million 2 ~ 4
      Million

      SAM size definitions

      Use the following table to calculate your SAM deployment size. 

      Deployment size Small Medium Large Note
      Maximum number of installed devices per instance < 0.5 million < 1.5 million < 3 million Devices include both virtual and physical machines. The SAM deployment size calculates the total number of devices across all tenants. 

      If you're dealing with products with large volume sizes, it's advisable to conduct calculation tasks separately within the production environment. For example, if you have 300,000 (0.3 million) devices using Windows Desktop OS across all the production tenants, you can:

      • (Advisable) Perform separate calculation jobs: In this case, the total number of devices is 0.3 M, so you only need to select the Small size.

      • Schedule concurrent calculation jobs: For each tenant, the maximum number of concurrent jobs is 3. When running three concurrent calculation jobs for three products that have the same volume size as Windows Desktop OS, the total number of devices is: 0.3 M X 3 = 0.9 M. As a result, you need to select the Medium size.

      In SAM production environment, the default deployment size is Small. To change the size after installation, see Change the SAM deployment size after installation.

      DND size definitions 

      Use the following table to calculate your DND deployment size. Note that this table applies to one DND instance. If you will enable DND for multiple tenants (one DND Instance per tenant), you need to calculate the deployment size of each individual DND instance. 

      DND deployment size Small Medium Large Notes
      Number of cloud subscriptions per hour 30 60 - The numbers in the table are approximate for a given deployment environment, but not exact. For example, a Small environment may only create 5 offerings, or 10 per category, although the table lists a representative number of 20. In your anticipated environment, you may find the expected numbers of tenants to span multiple profile definitions (for example, the number of active subscriptions may fit the Small deployment, while the number of offerings may fit the Medium profile). In such a case, select the profile that seems most representative of your anticipated environment, with the number of total subscriptions of particular importance. The sizing configuration is based on the results of performance lab tests in these deployment environments. In general, you should find the need to tune the configuration parameters after the installation, as you can manually scale the components as needed, to support the size of the environment you have specified.
      Number of active subscriptions 1,000 7,500 -
      Number of canceled subscriptions 10,000 50,000 -
      Number of offerings per category 20 20 -
      Total number of designs 35 75 -

      Cloud Cost Reporting size definitions

      The sizing for Cloud Cost Reporting primarily relies on the volume of billing data under management. This, of course, increases with the number of tenants, yet each tenant may have significantly different volumes of data. Cloud Cost Reporting runs a single set of Kubernetes pods for all tenants and doesn't require extra instances per tenant.

      The volume of billing data most directly affects the amount of database storage needed in Vertica. However, processing the data also consumes CPU and memory. Cloud Cost Reporting scales vertically, so increasing the size (CPU/memory) for workers is an effective strategy for larger volumes of data. Adding extra workers can help when insufficient resources are available in a small worker pool. Keep in mind that adding multiple worker nodes specifically for Cloud Cost Reporting isn't effective.

      Use the number of tenants and an estimation of an average monthly data volume for cloud billing records as a proxy to select between Small, Medium, and Large deployment sizes. Regard the accompanying Vertica database as independent of the base deployment sizes and adjust it to accommodate the data volume. Said another way, a single-tenant deployment may run in a small Kubernetes cluster, yet still require a large amount of storage for data in Vertica. The following table is a rough guideline. 

      Number of Cloud Cost Reporting Tenants Average Monthly Data Profile
      1–3 <15 million records Small
      4–7 15–50 million records Medium
      > 7 >50 million records Large

      The size of the Vertica storage should be able to accommodate the desired volume of cloud billing data that you would like to store. Keep in mind that Vertica sizing is dependent on:

      • the amount of historical data. AWS keeps billing data in perpetuity; Azure, for 3 years. More Vertica storage is necessary when a longer history exists. For example, use a 6x, 12x, 36x or even larger (for AWS) multiplier (against the average monthly data size) to estimate the needed Vertica space.
      • the volume of cloud activity. For example, provisioning hundreds of EC2 instances per hour on a regular basis will require more storage than more limited usage.

      Operations Orchestration Containerized size definition

      The OO sizing is measured by the number of tenants you want to deploy.

      • To deploy OO Containerized for a 5-tenant support, use the oo_size_values.yaml file provided here.
      • To deploy OO Containerized for a 20-tenant support, use the oo_size_values.yaml file provided here.

      Calculate your hardware requirements

      Calculate your hardware requirements according to your deployment option and deployment size. 

      Hardware requirements for option 1  (Service Management) 

      See Hardware requirements for option 1.  

      Hardware requirements for option 2 (Service Management + SAM + UCMDB) 

      See Hardware requirements for option 2. 

      Hardware requirements for option 3 (Service Management + DND + OO Containerized + Cloud Cost Reporting)

      See Hardware requirements for option 3. 

      Hardware requirements for other options

      If none of the options described earlier suits your environment, see Hardware requirements for other options.

      Hardware and system configuration recommendations

      The following are some hardware and system configuration recommendations:

      CPU

      Processor:

      • Intel® 64 bit (x86_64)
      • AMD 64 bit (AMD64)

      Minimum processor speed: 2.5 GHz

      Storage

      Refer to Manage persistent storage for the suite for details.

      Network latency

      If you need to achieve high availability by locating the Kubernetes cluster nodes (control plane nodes and worker nodes) in different zones, the recommended network latency between the cluster nodes is 1 millisecond (ms) or less for best performance and stability.     

      Virtual machines configuration

      Configure DRS for virtual machines hosting the suite

      When using VMware to deploy the suite, don't allow automated migration for the virtual machines used by the suite (the control plane nodes, worker nodes, NFS server, and database server), which may cause unexpected downtime. You must configure Distributed Resource scheduler (DRS) as follows:

      • If your cluster consists of only virtual machines for the suite: Configure DRS to be “Manual” so that with vMotion turned on, migration of the VMs doesn’t happen unless triggered manually.
      • If your cluster consists of virtual machines for the suite and other applications: Configure DRS to be “Automated,” enable individual virtual machine automation levels, and then set the automation level for each of the virtual machines hosting the suite to "Manual," so that only these selected machines are not migrated to other ESX hosts. 

      Reserve CPU and memory resources for virtual machines

      Once you have created the virtual machines, reserve the CPU and Memory resources for Service Management. Don't share the resources with other virtual machines.

      To reserve CPU allocation for a virtual machine:

      1. From the vSphere Web Client, locate and right-click the virtual machine, and then select Edit Settings.
      2. Configure the following settings and then click OK:
        • Reservation: Guaranteed CPU allocation for this virtual machine (in MHz or GHz). Move the slider bar to the far right to reserve the maximum allowed CPU allocation.
        • Limit: Upper limit for this virtual machine’s CPU allocation. Select Unlimited to specify no upper limit.
        • Shares: Select Normal.

      To fully reserve the memory allocation on a virtual machine:

      1. Power off the virtual machine.
      2. In the vSphere Client, right-click the virtual machine from the inventory and select Edit Settings.
      3. In the Virtual Machine Properties window, select the Resources tab and select Memory.
      4. In the Resource Allocation panel, select the Reserve all guest memory (All locked) check box.
      5. Click OK.

      Plan resources for OData integration 

      Before starting to use the OData integration, please read Sizing guide for OData integration to determine if you need additional Datahub pods, read-only platform pods, and additional worker nodes.

      Related topics

      • For information on Vertica disk space requirements, see Disk Space Requirements for Vertica
      • (Optional) Install containerized UD/UCMDB
